Justice.prompt: For centuries, Black, Indigenous, and People Of Color (BIPOC) communities have suffered from white supremacist oppression (slavery, genocide, social, political and economic hurdles, etc). Now it’s time for the end of white supremacy - for BIPOC liberation, reparations, and collective evolution.

self.choice: If you are a BIPOC person, think about and share what reparations and/or land back would mean to you. If you’re not, think about how you can help.

society.choice: Organize to achieve land back and reparations through social, cultural, economic and political movements

sustainability.choice: Prioritize BIPOC / frontline (most affected) communities (at least 50% of funds) for services, healthcare, grants, training, and jobs when transitioning to a sustainable society as part of reparations (debts repaid that are owed).

Equity.prompt: Black, Indigenous, and People of Color (BIPOC) communities are still fighting for their rights to control their own destiny in legal battles for rights, security, health, and justice (such as #FlintWaterCrisis, #StopAsianHate, #IStandWithParkCannon, and #StandingRockWaterProtectors). We must protect progress and achieve equity.

self.choice: Make sure you can vote freely to make your voice heard or support frontline (targeted/affected) communities (#IStandWithParkCannon, #KeepKnocking) by listening, aligning, and acting.

Equity.society: Support movements to pass bills (like the John Lewis Voting Rights Act and For the People Act) to protect voting rights that were hard won by calling your representatives or protesting.
Equity.sustainability: Make sure impacted communities (like the black and brown Georgians, Michigonians, Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders (AAPI) communities, Standing Rock water protectors,) can control their own lives and environment through treaties, representation, and equal legal protections rooted in historic understanding.

Health.prompt: Honor your breath, the breath of all people, and the air itself as a way to center in health -- physical, mental and emotional.  For yourself, for your community, and for the earth.

self.choice: Take 5 minutes to deeply breathe some fresh air (meditate).

society.choice: Learn CPR to help people breathe.

sustainability.choice: Read and communicate the Green New Deal and other visions for a just transition to a regenerative economy - so we can all breathe a sigh of relief in clean air.

Health.prompt: Take steps to protect yourself, others, and the natural world.

self.choice: Get your coronavirus vaccine if safe for you.

society.choice: Call your members of Congress to advocate for Medicare For All.

sustainability.choice: Prevent further encroachment into wild places to protect environmental health.

Education.prompt: The American education system has many great qualities or intentions (it is ideally free and equal for all, supportive, representative, useful, engaging, consciously mindful, well-funded, and helps us thrive), it also has a lot of room to grow (it can be white supremacist, patriarchal, nationalistic, underfunded, unsupportive, punitive, disengaging, inequitable, and inadequate). Education is a vehicle and key piece of reparations.

self.choice: Mentor a student from an underfunded public school district or Read the 1619 Project.

society.choice: Organize a School Strike for Equity in funding and representation.

sustainability.choice: Run for school board on a Reparations platform.

Housing.prompt: We believe housing is a human right.  Everyone should have a home, and a sustainable world where everyone can live, breathe, eat, drink, and move - together - in harmony with the Earth, so that future generations and all Earthlings can enjoy this world. We can make housing universal and in harmony.

self.choice: Live in an affordable, comfortable home where you don’t worry about paying the bills - sanctuary.

society.choice: Support universal green housing efforts with transit connected, walkable communities through localized advocacy in your community through the Green New Deal Network.

sustainability.choice: Promote a Global Green New Deal - green public housing, localized farming and living, and rapid transit accessibility in city design at the national and global level.

Food.prompt: Let’s repair our bodies, and our relationships to the Earth and each other by growing and sharing food while honoring the land and water in which it grows.

self.choice: Take care of your body, all people, and the Earth by eating more plant-based meals.

society.choice: Advocate with your members of Congress for food stamps in the US and nutrition for all globally so everyone can get what they need to survive and thrive.

sustainability.choice: Support small farmers to employ sustainable farming practices and localize food supplies, instead of landscaping and harmful practices of factory farming in large-scale agribusiness.

Community.prompt: We can take responsibility for our own parts of the world by participating on a local level -- and get lots of  satisfaction from interacting with neighbors and being part of a community. Think global, and act local!

self.choice: Create a traffic calming street mural in a dangerous intersection. Ask local artists to join. Or, get to know your neighborhood while getting exercise by walking/biking to work and errands

society.choice: Organize community meetings to listen to neighbors’ needs and concerns.

sustainability.choice: Developing a Green Benefit District plan for your neighborhood.

Work.prompt: Work can and should be a place for liberation, balance, and positive change.  It’s one way we contribute to society and a sustainable future.

self.choice: Step Up: If you’re not usually in a leadership role, put your skills to use and/or refine them by accepting a position of leadership. Or: Step Back: If you feel like you are overly responsible, make space for and follow new leadership, and kick back after school/work to rest and totally let go of the day.

society.choice: Accept a position of leadership in your democratic Labor Union.

sustainability.choice: Establish zero waste guidelines for your workplace.

Energy.prompt: We have to invest time, energy and money into universal access to a clean, sustainable power grid.

self.choice: Install solar panels on your roof. Or, put up a clothes line for the ultimate solar clothes dryer.

society.choice: Start a clean power utility in your community.

sustainability.choice: Introduce a solar feed-in tariff for farmers to become sustainable and generate a secondary income.

Mutual Aid.prompt: Mutual aid (people coming together as communities to support each other directly with resources and services) is gaining ground as a concept and tactic for fulfilling needs and addressing systemic problems.

self.choice: Look up an online how-to video to repair a broken object or appliance

society.choice: Find or found a Fix-it Clinic in your area

sustainability.choice: Implement a right-to-repair policy; make planned obsolescence obsolete.

Mutual Aid.prompt: Mutual aid (people coming together as communities to support each other directly with resources and services) is gaining ground as a concept and tactic for fulfilling needs and addressing systemic problems.

self.choice: Provide a Skill Share session as a “Public Amateur”

society.choice: Organize a weekend Skill Share event with fellow "Public Amateurs"

Mutual Aid.sustainability: Build and maintain a community garden

Just Migration.prompt: As the climate crisis continues to worsen amidst tremendous social inequities, more people will be forced to flee their homes and seek new places to live.  It is critical that wealthy consumer nations anticipate and welcome those who have been displaced.

self.choice: Receive support, respect, and amnesty if you are an undocumented person and a path to status and citizenship if you choose. If you are not, read poetry/watch videos about migration struggles and solidarity.

society.choice: Advocate for migrants rights and services, by lobbying, protesting, civil disobedience, or direct service.

sustainability.choice: Help ensure migrants are some of the first to benefit from clean energy and practices.

Nature.prompt: Nature in all its forms has the right to exist, persist, maintain, and regenerate its vital cycles.

self.choice: Chill out under your favorite tree and observe seasonal changes

society.choice: Lobby local officials with the power to grant or deny permits to loggers.

sustainability.choice: Invest/transition the logger workers to tree farmers and eco-restoration workers.

Nature.prompt: Nature in all its forms has the right to exist, persist, maintain, and regenerate its vital cycles.

self.choice: Observe the cycle of the moon outside, from a window, or on an app ( ie. Sky Safari, Star Walk, Star Chart, Night Sky Pro, Pocket Universe)

society.choice: Observe bird behavior of individual birds, species, and interspecies  -- with other bird lovers if possible

sustainability.choice: Research the wisdom of the ancestors about how humans are connected to Earth and all her systems.

Recreation.prompt: All living things experience cycles of energy, materials, nutrients and information.  Humans need rest and play, just as nature relies on the seasons for rejuvenation.

self.choice: Spend time practicing painting, guitar, or gardening.

society.choice: Advocate for budgeting for public arts programs where we can collectively create and celebrate.

sustainability.choice: Ensure vacations and recreation are sustainable by lobbying for investment in bullet train systems and plastic alternative laws.

Environment.prompt: People, animals and plants are both part of and dependent upon an overall structure that provides the conditions and resources needed for survival.

self.choice: Clean your space and adopt some plants for a restful home.

society.choice: Ensure public green space is built, protected, rehabilitated, and maintained.

sustainability.choice: Clean up the oceans as an eco-tourist activity people are subsidized to do.

Decolonization.prompt: Systems created in colonized lands are based on the privilege and worldview of the oppressor.  The hierarchy they established is the basis of inequity, and is not sustainable for humans or for the planet.

self.choice: Pay a Land Tax to local Indigenous people

society.choice: Help fund and promote a Land Trust for local Indigenous people

sustainability.choice: Promote adoption of TEK on all Public Lands

Storytelling.prompt: Humans have always learned about the world through stories shared, so we must know those that reflect the truth of our full diversity.

self.choice: Imagine “being in another person’s shoes” to understand their perspective and how they might feel.

society.choice: Participate in a community storytelling project. Share your story and listen to others.

sustainability.choice: Attend your neighborhood Environmental Justice film festival.

Transport.prompt: Transportation generates the largest share of greenhouse gases.  Everyone is dependent on various forms for moving people and resources, so clean and equitable methods must be accessible to all.

self.choice: Make sure you can easily move around by living close to public transportation in a safe, walkable, bikeable city.

society.choice: Consider a career in public transportation planning, construction, maintenance, or operation to help people use comfortable, fast, reliable, accessible bullet trains in smart green cities.

sustainability.choice: Help facilitate the just transition of workers and communities to clean transportation that is convenient and serves everyone equally.

Transport.prompt: Transportation generates the largest share of greenhouse gases.  Everyone is dependent on various forms for moving people and resources, so clean and equitable methods must be accessible to all.

self.choice: Fix up your old bike that’s been collecting dust in the garage. Look for a tool library nearby or connect with a skillshare.

society.choice: Lobby your local city council to turn a 60s era urban freeway into a people-first boulevard.

sustainability.choice: Replace your city’s diesel bus fleet with electric buses with dedicated lane service.

Arts.prompt: Human creativity and expression are a source of joy, recreation, appreciation of beauty, social commentary, and ingenuity.  The arts --visual, music, dance, theater, poetry, literature -- reach people’s hearts as well as minds.

self.choice: Give yourself 1 hour a week to be creative. Or attend a music or animation class.

society.choice: Lobby officials to maintain public arts budget for youth in low-income areas and schools.

sustainability.choice: Make sure frontline communities are paid for their murals, songs, or games to communicate the GND and its benefits to society.

Resources.prompt: Natural resources are the basis of all we consume for survival . . .  and for our 22nd century lifestyle!  To reach sustainability it’s critical to close the loop connecting resource use & extraction, to energy use, to  zero waste

self.choice: Mend the small hole in your favorite socks — a stitch in time saves 9!

society.choice: Volunteer to help fix the gate at your local school.

sustainability.choice: Participate in a wetlands restoration project in your county.

Truth.prompt: Tell the truth. Demand the truth.  Strive to understand the truth.

self.choice: Learn about white privilege, supremacy, and American exceptionalism and the harm it’s caused.

society.choice: Organize an event where people share their stories, tactics, etc about overcoming oppression.

sustainability.choice: Integrate a truth and reconciliation process centered in schools to learn the truth and make reparations for climate justice.

self.choice: Join a 12-month group meditation practice following Stephen Levine’s “A Year to Live”

society.choice: Join a Threshold Choir to help families and the dying through the passing

sustainability.choice: Promote laws and ordinances for low-resource burial or cremation
